title: Observation of Ultra-Thin Polar Domains in La-doped HfO2
content: The discovery of ferroelectricity in the binary oxide, HfO2, whose ground state is not even polar, has sparked significant interest because of its compatibility with CMOS devices [1, 2]. Unlike proper ferroelectrics, in which the polarization is usually deteriorated by depolarization at nanoscale dimensions, polar Pca21-HfO2 demonstrates robust ferroelectricity down to the unit-cell scale [2]. However, several fundamental questions pertaining to the harnessing of ferroelectricity in HfO2, and related materials, remain open. These unresolved questions include: the switching mechanism of the ferroelectric domain, the nature of the ferroelectric-to-paraelectric transition, and pathways to stabilize films with only the ferroelectric phase [1, 3, 4]. However, atomic-scale characterization of HfO2 and its domains have been hindered by the polycrystalline and mixed-phase nature of HfO2 thin films [3, 4]. Stabilizing HfO2 with only single polar Pca21 phase is essential to resolve above questions unambiguously.
